A **wand of death** is a type of [wand](/wiki/Wand "Wand") that appears in *[Nethack](/wiki/Nethack "Nethack")*, and is among the most powerful types present.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 SporkHack](#SporkHack)

## Generation

The wand of death is one of the rarest wands, making up only 0.5% of randomly generated wands.

[Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus") is always generated with a wand of death.

Monsters with a [difficulty rating](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty") of 8 or more that are eligible for an [offensive item](/wiki/Offensive_item "Offensive item") have a 1⁄35 chance of receiving a wand of death.

## Description

[Zapping](/wiki/Zapping "Zapping") the wand of death in any direction fires a ray of death magic, similar to the [finger of death](/wiki/Spellbook_of_finger_of_death "Spellbook of finger of death"), that instantly kills almost any [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") it hits in its path, including the player character. As with all [ray](/wiki/Ray "Ray")-type wands, it can [rebound](/wiki/Rebound "Rebound"), and there is a chance that it will miss.

[Death](/wiki/Riders#Death "Riders"), [major demons](/wiki/Major_demon "Major demon"), [nonliving](/wiki/Nonliving "Nonliving") monsters, and monsters with [player-type magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") or [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") are [resistant to death magic](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance") and completely unaffected; Death in particular will actually be healed and become stronger. Conversely, [Pestilence](/wiki/Riders#Pestilence "Riders") and [Famine](/wiki/Riders#Famine "Riders") are still susceptible.

Zapping a wand of death directly at yourself results in an [instadeath](/wiki/Instadeath "Instadeath"), even if you have magic resistance or reflection, *unless* you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into any of the aforementioned unaffected monsters.

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") the wand will break it, resulting in a standard magical explosion that deals a flat 16 damage for each remaining charge; although referred to as a "death field" in the associated message, magic resistance is not necessary to survive this explosion. See [breaking wands](/wiki/Breaking_wands "Breaking wands") for details.

## Strategy

- *For the guaranteed wand from Orcus, see [Orcus#Strategy](/wiki/Orcus#Strategy "Orcus").*

The fabled [Gnome With the Wand of Death](/wiki/Gnome_With_the_Wand_of_Death "Gnome With the Wand of Death") is one of the major sources of [YASD](/wiki/YASD "YASD"); while an actual GWTWOD is very much an outlier scenario, it represents the much more likely possibility that any intelligent monster may find a wand that could end your game (to speak nothing of a wand of death specifically). It may be ideal to snag whatever wands you see as soon as possible, if only to keep them out of other monsters' hands; if an early wand discovery happens to be a wand of death, it should be saved only for immediate emergencies where the only alternative to not using a precious charge is dying. Be especially careful of rebounds and monsters with [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") if you lack reflection or [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") yourself, particularly if you bring one to [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban").

Identifying a wand of death is not too difficult: [engraving](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving") with the wand of death provides the same message as the [wand of sleep](/wiki/Wand_of_sleep "Wand of sleep"), but the latter is much more common. Zapping either wand will formally identify it, but beware of bouncing rays: even a sleep ray can prove fatal in the wrong circumstances, to say nothing of a death ray. The wand of death also has a base cost of 500 [zm](/wiki/Zm "Zm"), only shared with the [wand of wishing](/wiki/Wand_of_wishing "Wand of wishing"). Identifying one in the possession of a monster is much more difficult for obvious reasons—if you learn that a monster has a wand of death without having been instantly killed by it, beware of bouncing rays and consider using an [escape item](/wiki/Escape_item "Escape item") unless you have reflection or magic resistance.

Having reflection in particular tends to trivialize most of the wand's danger; if the reflected ray kills the user, you can then pick it up to preserve the remaining charges. [Pacifists](/wiki/Pacifist "Pacifist") with magic resistance or reflection may sometimes want to give a wand of death to a particularly dangerous monster in order to have them kill themselves with the rebounded/reflected ray—this is one of the pacifistic strategies for dealing with [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa"), though she must be blinded first as killing her via reflection breaks the conduct.

The wand of death is often employed in the late game to kill the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor"), both during the initial meeting and every reappearance after; this is done to minimize the risk of him stealing [quest artifacts](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"), especially ones that provide magic resistance. Make sure that @ isn't a [summoned](/wiki/Summon_nasties "Summon nasties") [Elvenking](/wiki/Elvenking "Elvenking") before taking your shot!

## History

The wand of death appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is also included in the initial item list for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Messages

- The bugs on the floor stop moving!

  You engraved with a [wand of sleep](/wiki/Wand_of_sleep "Wand of sleep") or a wand of death.

- You irradiate yourself with pure energy!  
  You die.

  You zapped a wand of death directly at yourself.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- The wand shoots an apparently harmless beam at you.

  As above, but you are polymorphed into a form immune to death rays.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), various monsters have [death resistance](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance"), which prevents them from dying immediately if hit by the wand, though they will still take damage. This includes a few monsters that would otherwise make enticing targets for a wand of death, such as the [minotaur](/wiki/Minotaur "Minotaur"), forcing you to dispose of them through an alternate means.

A wand of death is always generated in [the Spider Caves](/wiki/The_Spider_Caves "The Spider Caves").

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), death rays from the wand and other sources will still cause damage and reduce your maximum hit points if you have magic resistance or reflection. If you have both properties, the damage and maximum HP loss are dramatically reduced.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [metroids](/wiki/Metroid "Metroid") that are hit by death rays will not only be unaffected, but use the energy to [divide](/wiki/Divide "Divide") or bud - if you are hit by a death ray while polymorphed into a metroid, you are instead healed for 3d10 HP.

[The Wand of Orcus](/wiki/The_Wand_of_Orcus_\(dNetHack\) "The Wand of Orcus (dNetHack)") is an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") huge-sized wand of death that Orcus himself always generates with. It uses the mace skill when wielded as a melee weapon and has +1d20 to-hit, and on hit it deals +1d12 damage and drains one level from non-[drain resistant](/wiki/Drain_resistant "Drain resistant") targets. The Wand of Orcus is also [bloodthirsty](/wiki/Bloodthirsty "Bloodthirsty"), with a base 1⁄4 chance of passively attacking adjacent monsters each turn. As a wand, it can be charged indefinitely and cannot be wrested or broken - [invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") the Wand allows it to be zapped as a wand of death without consuming a charge.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), the [wand of wonder](/wiki/Wand_of_wonder "Wand of wonder") is capable of replicating the effects of a wand of death.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), wands of death function similarly to SporkHack, and additionally can only be recharged once.

Orcus does not generate with a wand of death, instead using the unique artifact [Wand of Orcus](/wiki/Wand_of_Orcus "Wand of Orcus") (which his guaranteed wand in *NetHack* represents).

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, the Gnome King's Apiary variant of [Mines' End](/wiki/Mines%27_End "Mines' End") has a guaranteed wand of a death in a small 2x2 area that is only accessible by [phasing](/wiki/Phasing "Phasing") and is guarded by four hostile [air elementals](/wiki/Air_elemental "Air elemental").

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), wands of death function as in EvilHack, and the wand of wonder is capable of replicating the effects of a wand of death as in SpliceHack.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2458](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/zap.c#L2458): *This hard-coded message ("You die.") is different than the standard "You die..."*
